awd_titl_txt: Investigations of Binary Transition Metal Oxide Electrocatalysts for the Oxygen Evolution Reaction
awd_abstract_narration:
Some energy conversion and storage technologies use chemical reactions driven by electricity in a process known as electrocatalysis. Examples of these technologies include new metal-air batteries, water splitting for hydrogen evolution, and production of chemicals from the carbon dioxide (the byproduct of burning fossil fuels). All of these technologies share a crucial chemical reaction known as the oxygen evolution reaction (OER).  The efficiencies of these technologies are often limited by the sluggish rate of the OER. In this project, Dr. Bruce E. Koel of Princeton University is conducting experiments on iridium (Ir) and cobalt (Co) based mixed oxide materials to develop a greater fundamental understanding of the OER.  This project may lead to the discovery of novel electrocatalytic materials to enhance OER. Dr. Koel's research prepares students for careers in high-tech and emerging industries that value the ability to solve complex problems and that utilize sophisticated instrumentation. Undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students are involved in the research and work together to conduct experiments, construct theoretical models, provide physical insight, and develop new explanations. The importance of this research for addressing the energy needs of the planet enhances student awareness of the impact of their work on society. This research prepares students for careers in academia, national laboratories, and industry.

With support from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry and Catalysis and Biocatalysis Program in the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environment and Transport Systems, Dr. Koel is conducting experiments on Ir and Co based mixed oxide electrocatalysts that are providing a greater fundamental understanding of OER electrocatalysis. Establishing clear relationships between atomic level surface properties and performance of active electrodes provides a better understanding of electrocatalysts for OER and provides rational strategies for improving OER kinetics. Active structures/motifs are identified during OER by operando Raman spectroscopy and key aspects of the water oxidation mechanism are revealed by identification of surface species during OER by operando Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy along with fundamental surface science experiments. Iridium based oxide catalysts are studied with the prospect of forming superior OER catalysts.  The researcher also seek to reduce the loading of the expensive Ir metal and provide new materials for the development of cost-effective, high performance, stable OER catalysts. Cobalt based oxide catalysts are investigated because of their OER performance under alkaline conditions.  They have potential for increasing catalyst activity and possibly lowering the pH range of operation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Addressing the growing global energy demand is a grand challenge facing science and engineering in the 21st century. Development of renewable energy technologies to generate power and reduce fossil fuel consumption is integral to achieving energy sustainability. The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) plays an essential role in many energy conversion and storage technologies, including metal-air batteries, water splitting for hydrogen evolution, and CO2 reduction for hydrocarbon production. Efficiently driving the oxygen evolution reaction represents a critical technological hurdle. The electrocatalysis community has a great need for clear relationships between atomic level surface properties and performance of active electrodes, which are difficult to establish using the complex, fully optimized materials at the fore. This research was aimed at adding to such information. In addition, new rational strategies are needed for catalyst discovery and optimization. Iridium(Ir)-based and ruthenium(Ru)-based oxide catalysts were studied with the prospect of forming superior OER catalysts with reduced Ir or Ru loading (due to their high cost) and providing new materials for the development of cost-effective, high performance, stable OER catalysts. Cobalt(Co)-based oxide catalysts were investigated because of their great OER performance under alkaline conditions and the potential that early transition metal modifiers can increase catalyst activity and possibly lower the pH range of operation. In this research, we have pursued the synthesis of highly active and stable Ir-, Ru-, and Co-based oxide catalysts, e.g., through the incorporation of early transition metals that have the potential to increase catalyst activity and possibly lower the pH range of operation. The systematic studies of this project have sought to reveal the enhancement mechanisms in these binary oxide electrocatalysts, provide guidance for designing better OER catalysts, and discover new highly performing electrocatalysts for OER.

In this project we synthesized M-modified Ir-, Ru-, and Co-oxide catalysts where M = zirconium (Zr), titanium (Ti), or hafnium (Hf). We investigated their performance for electrocatalysis of O2 evolution in either basic and acidic solution, and sought detailed mechanistic information on the active sites for OER. In some cases, we also tested the performance of these catalysts for other electrochemical reactions, and in a few select cases discovered additional high performance of these catalysts for other reactions. We used advanced imaging and spectroscopic characterization to establish relationships between catalyst composition/structure and OER activity. We were able in some cases to identify active structures/motifs by simultaneous measurements of catalytic performance and structure during OER, in particular by using operando Raman spectroscopy, and determine the influence of transition-metal modifiers on the active structures. We discovered a highly active, Hf-modified Ir-oxide catalyst (IrHfxOy) for OER under both acidic and alkaline conditions. This electrocatalyst demonstrated ten times higher activity in alkaline conditions and four times higher activity in acid conditions than a pure Ir-oxide electrocatalyst. Combined studies utilizing operando surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) and quantum calculations revealed the active sites for OER reactions on this catalyst. We also found that the activity and stability of Ru-oxide nanoparticle catalysts for OER could be tremendously improved by synthesizing Hf-phosphate-supported Ru-oxide nanoparticles. This catalyst exhibited an impressive activity and stability for OER that was superior to commercial Ru-oxide catalysts on the electrode. These results provide solid evidence that will aid rational design of more cost-effective, stable electrocatalysts with improved OER performance.

The obtained information in this work is useful beyond the specific results contributing to a better overall understanding of the relationships between composition and structure and OER activity of catalysts, and the nature of active structures/motifs in these catalysts. For example, the project results are useful in the development of new strategies for catalyst and nanomaterials synthesis and characterization. In broader applications, this improved understanding of electrocatalysts for OER can provide rational strategies for improving OER kinetics and thus advancing the realization of the full potential of many emergent energy conversion and storage technologies.

The project results were presented at multiple scientific conferences and published in peer-reviewed journals. The project provided opportunities for training, development and mentoring of graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral researchers. The outreach programs included the development of new educational materials related to the research activities and results.


Last Modified: 05/19/2022
Modified by: Bruce E Koel
